questions.text: What is Jackson Rees circuit used for?
questions.solution:
The Jackson-Rees modification of Ayre's T-piece incorporates an open-ended bag attached to the end of the reservoir tubing. Partially occluding the 'tail' of the bag permits positive pressure ventilation or the application of PEEP. The bag also gives a visual indication of ventilation.

Gas dynamics during spontaneous or controlled ventilation are similar to Mapleson E systems. FGF of 2-3 times MV is required.

Advantages:

  • Positive pressure ventilation and PEEP are possible.
  • More suitable for inhalational induction than a circle system.
  • This is the standard breathing system for paediatric patients (up to 25 kg) although a small calibre circle system may also be used.

Disadvantages:

  • Scavenging is difficult.
  • The system is inefficient, requiring high FGFs.
  • Partially occluding the tail, whilst at the same time squeezing the bag is a moderately skilled technique.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B) Cardiac Anesthesia - Incorrect

  • Not preferred in cardiac anesthesia, where more controlled ventilation and closed-circuit systems (e.g., circle system) are used.
  • High fresh gas flow (FGF) requirements make it inefficient for prolonged cardiac cases.

Choice C) Neuro Anesthesia - Incorrect

  • Neuroanesthesia typically involves tight control of CO2 levels, which is better achieved using circle systems with CO2 absorbers.
  • The Jackson-Rees circuit lacks CO2 absorption and is not ideal for controlled ventilation in neuroanesthesia.

Choice D) Obstetric Anesthesia - Incorrect

  • Obstetric cases often require precise control of airway pressures and low FGF to avoid waste.
  • The circle system or ventilators are preferred over the Jackson-Rees circuit, which is inefficient due to high FGF requirements.

Key Takeaway:

The Jackson-Rees circuit is the standard breathing system for pediatric patients due to its low resistance, ability to deliver PPV, and visual monitoring of ventilation.

questions.text: A female following a road traffic accident injured her chest. On x-ray there is a fracture of third to fifth ribs, pain was not responsive to the routine analgesics. Which of the following blocks should be given?
questions.solution:
Ribs are supplied by the thoracic intercostal nerves which arise from the thoracic spinal nerves T1 to T11.

Analgesia for patients having thoracic trauma can be achieved with intravenous narcotics or local anesthetic administration, which avoids the potential respiratory depression common with systemic narcotics.

Options for administering local anesthetics include intermittent intercostal nerve block(s) and transcutaneous intrapleural, extrapleural, or epidural anesthesia. When used properly, local anaesthetic agents can provide excellent analgesia and prevent the need for intubation.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A) Cervical Block - Incorrect

  • The cervical plexus (C1-C4) supplies the neck and upper shoulder, not the thoracic region.
  • Not useful for rib fractures or thoracic pain management.

Choice B) Supraclavicular Block - Incorrect

  • A brachial plexus block primarily used for upper limb surgeries.
  • It does not provide analgesia for thoracic trauma or rib fractures.

Choice C) Lumbar Epidural - Incorrect

  • Blocks lower spinal nerves (L1-L5), making it useful for lower abdominal and lower limb surgeries.
  • Does not cover thoracic spinal nerves, so it cannot provide adequate analgesia for rib fractures.

Key Takeaway:

Thoracic epidural block is the preferred analgesic technique for thoracic trauma, as it effectively blocks thoracic spinal nerves and provides superior pain relief, reducing complications.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs will cause adrenal suppression?
questions.solution:
Etomidate causes adrenocortical suppression by producing a dose-dependent

inhibition of the conversion of cholesterol to cortisol. The specific enzyme inhibited by etomidate appears to be 11-β-hydroxylase as evidenced by the accumulation of 11-deoxycorticosterone. This enzyme inhibition lasts 4 to 8 hours after an induction dose of etomidate.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A) Thiopental - Incorrect

  • A barbiturate used for induction but does not cause adrenal suppression.
  • Primarily acts on GABA-A receptors, causing sedation and hypnosis.

Choice B) Ketamine - Incorrect

  • NMDA receptor antagonist, used for dissociative anesthesia.
  • Does not suppress adrenal function.
  • In fact, ketamine stimulates the sympathetic nervous system, increasing catecholamine release.

Choice D) Propofol - Incorrect

  • GABA-A receptor agonist, used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia.
  • Does not inhibit adrenal function or cortisol production.

Key Takeaway:

Etomidate causes adrenal suppression by inhibiting 11-β-hydroxylase, leading to decreased cortisol production. This effect makes it unsuitable for critically ill patients, particularly in sepsis.

choices.text: It achieves maximum concentration in the brain after an IV infusion
Redistribution to adipose tissue and muscle is seen
Rapid decline in its effect is due to renal excretion

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding thiopentone sodium?
questions.solution:
Thiopental causes rapid onset and rapid awakening after a single IV dose due to rapid uptake then rapid redistribution out of the brain into inactive tissues. This is the basis for its short action as it is a highly lipophilic drug.

Ultimately, elimination from the body depends almost entirely on metabolism because less than 1% of thiopental is recovered unchanged in urine.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A) It is lipid soluble - Correct

  • Thiopental is highly lipid-soluble, which allows for rapid CNS penetration and fast onset of action.

Choice B) It achieves maximum concentration in the brain after an IV infusion - Correct

  • After IV administration, peak brain concentration is reached within seconds due to its high lipid solubility.

Choice C) Redistribution to adipose tissue and muscle is seen - Correct

  • Rapid redistribution from the brain to muscle and fat is the primary reason for termination of effect, rather than metabolism or excretion.

Key Takeaway:

Thiopental has a rapid onset and short duration due to redistribution from the brain to muscle and adipose tissue, not due to renal excretion. Its metabolism occurs mainly in the liver, with minimal renal elimination.

choices.text: Revascularisation procedure, if patient develops ST elevation post resuscitation
Bring the body temperature down to below 32°, therapeutic hypothermia if unresponsive.

questions.text: Which of the following must be avoided in a patient with post cardiac arrest resuscitation care?
questions.solution:
Survival after cardiac arrest is largely dependent on the patient's co-morbidities and the initial hypoxic insults to the heart and brain. However, survival is also influenced by subsequent complications, including secondary insults, the ensuing systemic inflammatory response and differences in post-resuscitation care.

The International consensus recommendation is that unconscious haemodynamically stable survivors of out of hospital cardiac arrest should be cooled to 32 to 36°C for 24 hours. Care should be taken if using the upper level of this range to ensure that fever is avoided. A period of induced hypothermia should also be considered for cardiac arrest due to other rhythms as well as in hospital arrests.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A) Maintain MAP over 65 - Correct

  • A mean arterial pressure (MAP) ≥ 65 mmHg is essential to maintain organ perfusion and prevent secondary ischemic injury.

Choice B) Maintain SpO2 above 94% - Correct

  • Maintaining oxygen saturation (SpO2) between 94-98% prevents hypoxia and hyperoxia, both of which can worsen neurological outcomes.

Choice C) Revascularization procedure if patient develops ST elevation post-resuscitation - Correct

  • Immediate coronary angiography and revascularization are recommended in patients with ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) post-cardiac arrest.

Key Takeaway:

Post-cardiac arrest care includes maintaining MAP ≥ 65 mmHg, SpO2 > 94%, and revascularization if indicated. Therapeutic hypothermia should be maintained at 32-36°C, but temperatures below 32°C should be avoided due to potential complications.

questions.text: Ambu aura 40 is an example of
questions.solution:
Supraglottic airway device (SAD) or extraglottic airway device, is a medical device that maintains upper airway patency during anesthesia or unconscious situation. It also allows for limited intermittent positive-pressure ventilation (IPPV), offers some degree of protection against the aspiration of gastric contents, and can be used easily especially because it can be inserted atraumatically by a low-skilled practitioner

First Generation SGA: Simple breathing tube, usually with some form of mask or opening at the larynx. Examples: Classic LMA, LMA-Unique, SureSeal LM, Cobra PLA, Laryngeal Tube Airway.

Second Generation SGA: In general, it has provision for gastric drainage, better sealing through a posterior inflatable cuff that improved protection against aspiration, in addition to integral bite block. Examples: Combi-tube, Pro-seal LMA, LMA-Supreme, I-Gel, LTS-D, Air-Q, Aura-Gain, Protector, LMA Gastro.

Third Generation SGA: Has dynamic sealing mechanism plus double suction ports, in addition to the characteristic of the second Generation. Examples: Baska, Elisha, and 3G LM.

Since the Ambu aura 40 doesn't have a channel for gastric suctioning, it is also a first generation supraglottic device.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B) Supraglottic laryngeal airway generation 2 - Incorrect

  • Second-generation SADs include gastric drainage ports for improved airway protection and aspiration prevention.
  • Examples: LMA ProSeal, I-Gel, LMA Supreme, Air-Q, LTS-D.
  • Ambu Aura 40 does not have a gastric drainage channel, so it does not belong to this category.

Choice C) Supraglottic laryngeal airway generation 3 - Incorrect

  • Third-generation SADs incorporate dynamic sealing mechanisms, double suction ports, and enhanced airway protection features.
  • Examples: Baska Mask, Elisha, 3G LMA.
  • Ambu Aura 40 lacks these advanced features, so it is not classified under this category.

Choice D) Supraglottic laryngeal airway generation 4 - Incorrect

  • There is currently no widely accepted classification for a fourth-generation supraglottic airway device.

Key Takeaway:

Ambu Aura 40 is a first-generation supraglottic airway device because it lacks a gastric drainage port and advanced sealing mechanisms.
